description: Perfume advertised as a symbol of femininity, grace, and social ritual, reinforcing romantic and domestic ideals through ornate, pastel visuals.
Perfume used to reinforce strict gender roles: glamorous housewives, alpha businessmen, seductresses. Visuals were bold, polished, and status-driven.
Advertising split between minimalist unisex rebellion (e.g., CK One) and hyper-gendered celebrity fragrances, reflecting a cultural tug-of-war around gender norms.
Perfume shifted toward self-expression, emotion, and personal storytelling. Visuals embraced editorial minimalism, poetic neutrality, and niche-driven aesthetics focused on personal meaning.
